titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Hare Family Papers
1873-1962 (Bulk 1884-1930)
MS 277
titlestmt.author: Processed by Maurita Baldock

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 15:48:42 -0400.

did.unittitle: Hare Family Papers
did.abstract: The Hare Family Papers consist of the personal papers of New York City attorney Montgomery Hare (1870-1932), his wife Constance Parsons Hare (1873-?), and material by the Parsons family.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Donation by Peter H. Hare, grandson of Montgomery and Constance Hare, 1999.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.) See guidelines in Reading Room for details.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Permission to quote from this collection in a publication must be requested and granted in writing. Send permission requests, citing the name of the collection from which you wish to quote, to
Library Director
The New-York Historical Society
170 Central Park West
New York, NY 10024

The copyright law of the United States governs the making of photocopies and protects unpublished materials as well as published materials. Unpublished materials created before January 1, 1978 cannot be quoted in publication without permission of the copyright holder.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as the Hare Family Papers, the New-York Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical Summary For Montgomery Hare and Constance Parsons Hare:

eventgrp.event: Montgomery Hare born in Orange, New Jersey to J. Montgomery Hare and Mary Meredith Hare. His siblings include Meredith, William, Morin, and Mary.
Constance Parsons born to John E. Parsons and Mary McIlvaine Parsons, the youngest of six children including Mary (Mamie), Edith, Helen, Herbert, and Gertrude.
Montgomery Hare attends Groton School in Massachusetts.
He receives his B.A. from Yale University.
Montgomery Hare graduates from Columbia University Law School and is admitted to the bar.
He holds the office of Assistant Corporation Counsel in New York City.
Montgomery Hare runs unsuccessfully for Alderman of the 31st Aldermanic District.
With Thomas E. Rush, Montgomery Hare forms law partnership Rush & Hare.
Montgomery Hare and Constance Parsons are married.
First son Michael Meredith Hare born.
Montgomery Hare ends law partnership with Thomas E. Rush and establishes the firm, Shearn & Hare with Clarence J. Shearn.
Montgomery Hare dies on July 8, at the age of sixty-two.
Constance Parsons Hare turns eighty years old. The date of her death is unclear.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Hare Family Papers largely document the personal relationships within the Hare family and within the Parsons family, which was the family of Montgomery Hare's wife Constance. The bulk of the material is correspondence among family members. Neither Montgomery Hare's nor John E. Parsons's business affairs are represented within this collection.

The collection represents family relationships in the late nineteenth and early twentieth century. Parent/child relationships are represented through the letters to Montgomery Hare from his parents while he was away at school and later Hare's letters to his own children while they were away. Family relationships are also documented in the letters to Constance Parsons Hare from her children and her sisters.
The Library of Congress Name Authority File spells the family name "Hare" as "Hair."

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged according to family member or type of material.
The papers are organized into the following seven series:

list.head: Missing Title
list.item: Series 4: Other Members of the Hare and Parsons Family, 1917-1929, undated

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at The New-York Historical Society
relatedmaterial.p: Further material relating to Constance Parsons Hare and the Parsons family can be found within the Parsons Family Papers at the New-York Historical Society.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Oversize diplomas and photographs are stored in the small oversize case, drawer one.

controlaccess.geogname: New York (N.Y.) -- Social life and customs.
controlaccess.subject: Families -- New York (State) -- New York.
Family -- New Jersey -- Orange.
Decedents' estates

did.unittitle: Series 1: Montgomery Hare, 1884-1930, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains the personal materials of Montgomery Hare. It mainly includes incoming personal correspondence from family members and his wife-to-be, Constance Parsons. His correspondence also contains a 1930 form letter signed by Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt. The one folder of outgoing correspondence includes letters to his sons away at school and camp. The letters are arranged alphabetically by sender or recipient and then chronologically. The series also includes Hare's saved material such as writings, school records, policies, and certificates.

Series 2: Constance Parsons Hare, 1873-1962, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials relating to the life of Constance Parsons Hare. Most of the correspondence is from family members, particularly her sons and her sisters. Specific letters include a thank you letter from poet Edith Sitwell and two letters from Gertrude Parsons describing conditions in Germany and Paris after the end of World War I. Personal documents such as her will, a family tree, and a list of the monetary value of her property are also included.

did.unittitle: Constance Parsons: Letters received from A-O
Constance Parsons: Letters received from P-T
Constance Parsons: Outgoing letters to various correspondents
Will of Constance Parsons Hare
List of auction and insurance values for property of Constance Parsons Hare
Family Trees and Genealogical Information for Constance Parsons Hare
Series 3: John Edward Parsons, 1910-1916 undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes the documents in the collection relating to John E. Parsons, the father of Constance Parsons Hare. Only one folder in this series contains correspondence, and it consists of letters written to John E. Parsons from his daughter, Gertrude Parsons. The other folders contain John E. Parsons's will and legal information regarding his estate.

did.unittitle: John E. Parsons: Letters received from Gertrude Parsons
Will of John E. Parsons
Documents relating to estate of John E. Parsons
Series 4: Other Members of the Hare and Parsons Families, 1917-1929, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of materials relating to other members of the Hare or Parsons families. It contains one folder of correspondence from Michael Meredith Hare and Montgomery Hare Jr. (the sons of Montgomery and Constance Parsons Hare), one folder of incoming and outgoing correspondence of Mary Parsons (Constance Parsons Hare's sister), and two passports for Gertrude Parsons (another sister of Constance Parsons Hare).

did.unittitle: Michael Meredith Hare and Montgomery Hare, Jr.: Letters sent to various correspondents
Mary Parsons: Letters sent and received
Passports for Gertrude Parsons
Series 5: Clippings, 1908-1929, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of one folder of newspaper or magazine clippings that mention members of the Hare or Parsons family. Many of the clippings are wedding announcements for Montgomery and Constance Parsons Hare. The one folder of clippings unrelated to either family contains mostly articles on local and national politics.

did.unittitle: Clippings regarding Hare and/or Parsons Family Members
Clippings, unrelated to Hare and/or Parsons Family
Series 6: Memorabilia, 1896-1951, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The memorabilia series includes saved ephemera such as invitations, receipts, programs, a brochure, and a menu. Although some of the theater programs attribute plays to Montgomery Hare, it is unclear if the playwright was Montgomery Hare, the elder, or his son of the same name.

did.unittitle: Invitations and Announcements
Receipts
Theater Programs
Travel Brochures and Menu
Series 7: Photographs, 1915-1953, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The series includes snapshots and posed portraits. They are divided into the following categories: photographs of members of the Hare family, photographs of members of the Parsons family, and unidentified subjects. Although many of the subjects are identified on the backs of the photos, most of the images are undated.

did.unittitle: Photographs, Members of Hare Family
Photographs, Members of Parsons Family
Photographs, Unidentified people
